transcripts.text: Saad in Karachi, you're talking to Eric and Matt.
Hey!  Hey Saad.
So Matt, just...
Hey, I'm so glad to talk to you again.

Happy to talk to you too.  So Matt, last time Saad called in, it was toward the end of the show, and Saad had said that there was a lot of scientific evidence that is found in the Quran, which makes the Quran, you know, true.  And so we said, hey, could you give us some of that evidence?  Let's investigate it.  and saad said well i actually don't have that on me.  and so we invited them to call back cool and so saad is calling back.
can we make sure we cautiously go through one thing at a time and not like 20 things?
well yeah i mean i i think saad would understand that we'd have to you know piece them through.  right oh okay all right.  so what what which what evidence did you want to bring forward today?
well first is on embryonic development.  so uh this is uh so the chapters uh from the quran is chapter 23 verse 12 to 14.

is this where it describes?  describes the embryo.  embryo is looking like chewed gum.  yes yeah how is that remotely scientific evidence of anything?  because and i'm asking this do you think that people there at that time had never seen an embryo.  Well, they hadn't, but God had.  No, why would you... Okay, see, this is a problem with people in modern culture, especially city people, who think that people who were farmers and ranchers did not see... Embryos.  Miscarriages happen all the time with animals and with humans.  The very notion that at any point in recorded history there was nobody who was familiar with what an embryo looked like is bizarre.  It's absurd.  We've always known.  Now, what we knew about it specifically is perhaps subject to debate.  But saying that there's an embryo that looks like chewed gum is absurd.  That is not surprising, and it doesn't enlighten us about anything at all.  that's scientific.  So here's a passage that isn't remarkable, and yet you're viewing it as if there's some profound scientific information there when there's not.
Hello?

Yeah, yeah.  In my opinion, well, I can understand where you're coming from, but 1,400 years ago back, You know, when the Arabs back then, there were a lot of illiterate people over there.  There were really no scientists or doctors or engineers back then.
Do you think that I mentioned scientists or doctors?  Yeah, saying something looks like chewed gum is not scientific.

But also, I didn't mention science or doctors.  I mentioned farmers and people.  Miscarriages happened at an astonishing rate back then, and anybody who was a rancher knew about this.  We knew about breeding even before we knew about genetics.  This is how we ended up with domesticated animals and dogs.  How many people have cracked open a chicken egg?  I did this.  Just three or four weeks ago, with an egg that came directly from the grocery store, I crack it open, there's an embryo in it, because we can't catch all of them.  That's true.
That's gross, by the way.

To point to this passage and say, hey, look, the Quran describes an embryo as if it was chewed gum.  is like saying, hey, 1400 years ago, or actually 700 years ago, people look back and some of those people then would have described this as if it was chewed gum or some sort of mass.  Yes, they would have.  And there's absolutely nothing in that passage that it was of any scientific value.  And the other problem here, which you're gonna get to when you get to your next one, is that when people say, oh, well, the Bible tells us things about science or the Quran tells us things about science, even if the Quran said, Even if the Quran described the germ theory of disease, that is of no use to us as a pronouncement from a holy book until such time as science confirms it.  And then you also have to look at what other passages were made where the pronouncements were actually shown to be wrong by science.  So when we talk about the Quran having passages that, oh, these couldn't have been known by people, Well, that's the first one people go to.  It's the first one you went to.  And yet I think that you would have to admit it's not remarkable at all.  People would have known this.  Some people, not everybody.  But it doesn't matter who's illiterate or that most were illiterate.  Somebody knew this and wrote it down.  You don't have to appeal to a god revealing information when it can happen when you crack open an egg or when your wife or one of your farm animals miscarries.
What do you think, Saad?  Does that evidence that you brought forward kind of maybe not hold as much weight?

Well, honestly speaking, you guys always have good answers to these things.  And I'm not really an expert on the Klan myself.  So for me to... All I did basically was... I tried to look at certain articles, I mean, at certain passages and try to understand what they mean.  And this one was very interesting because in my opinion, back then, the only way you could get information like this is from divine sources.
Okay, hang on.  No, no, no, no, no, no.  Hold on.  That's not even remotely true.

First of all, the fact that it's your opinion that the only way they could have got that information was a divine source is completely irrelevant.  It's whether or not you have an informed opinion.  Have you studied the history?  Have you seen what other writings there were?  Do you know what people knew about biology back then?
Well, I've studied Islamic history, and I know that back then, those were the dark ages.  I mean, they would literally bury babies alive back then.
That doesn't answer my question.
Does that remotely respond to the fact that people had seen those kinds of things at the time?
You've reached the conclusion that here's a report on something, and you've said the only way they could have known that was through divine intervention.
Have you excluded time travelers?
Oh, no, God.

Well, I mean, there are tons and tons of other explanations, not just some kind of divine source.  I mean, what you're doing is you're saying this is the very last thing.  It can only be this.  There are tons and tons and tons of other proposed things, right?  I mean... Really, kind of what I'm wondering is, Saad, are you investigating this and wanting to know the truth, or are you saying, I already have the truth, I'm looking for evidence that backs up my conclusion?
Well, it's a bit of both.
Why would you do the latter at all?
The latter to investigate the truth or to know the truth?
No.  Why would you say, I have the answer, I'm only going to look up what confirms my answer?  I'm only going to find evidence that confirms what I've already concluded.

I'm going to tell you a quick story, because it comes right out of my show.  Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and Harry Houdini were good friends.  And Sir Arthur Conan Doyle famously wrote Sherlock Holmes and gave this statement of, once you've eliminated all other possibilities, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the right answer.  And a lot of people think that this is a profound statement on skepticism.  It's not.  It is a fallacious thing.  I call it Doyle's fallacy.  Because the question is, how do you know you've eliminated all the possible explanations?  In your case, and this is where we get an argument from personal incredulity, which is a fallacy, you took a look at this, and based on the information you have, you don't think there's any way somebody could have known what an embryo looked like.  And you also seem to think that chewed gum is an accurate description of embryo, which I would not say it actually is.  And because you couldn't Your information did not allow you to come up with any other explanation.  You jumped to the explanation that the best or only explanation was divine intervention.  When Houdini would escape from ropes and chains, he would escape and the ropes would still be tied in knots and the chains would still be secured.  And Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, in his infinite genius, concluded that he had ruled out all other possibilities and reached the conclusion that Houdini could physically dematerialize.  This was his explanation for how Houdini could escape.  We know that this is not the case.  I can escape from things and have escaped from things.  Even, well, it's not much to say faster than Houdini because Houdini would sometimes take forever.  But... I can do those things, escape from ropes where the ropes are still knotted, would it be reasonable for anybody to conclude that I can actually dematerialize?  Of course not, because they can't have eliminated other possibilities.  And so you're looking at the Quran and seeing this passage, and you're committing what I call Doyle's fallacy.  You look at it and you say, wow, I can't imagine how people could have known about embryos, so it must have been divine knowledge and divine intervention.  And yet I just described to you a number of different ways that people throughout all of recorded history and before could very well and likely did know about embryos.  So how is that not a more plausible explanation than God told them?

Well, at the same point, you're saying that it's possible that people knew about these things back then.  Let me say this to you.  Do you have any strong proof that, yes, there was one person back in 700 A.D.  or 600  A.D.,  whatever the time was, that actually knew about these things, other than what I'm telling you?
So hold on.  We're not actually making the claim.  We're investigating yours, Saad.

So the thing is, I offered an explanation that is plausible based on the bulk of information, the fact that we've been raising animals, the fact that we've been giving birth, the fact that miscarriages were higher, that infant mortality rates were higher.  And now you're saying you are implying, I shouldn't say saying, you are implying that unless I can give you proof that one person knew about this back then, you're sticking with the best explanation.  is God said so?
Well, wouldn't you?  No.
No, not even close.  Here's an example.

I would never have gone to.  God said so in the first place because that requires evidence.  My plausible explanations for how they could have known this have evidence to back them up.  And they are all completely natural and mundane.  You are reaching to the supernatural for which there is no evidence.  And what makes this worse is you are then trying to use this conclusion as if it is evidence for the supernatural, which makes your entire argument circular.  So you start with an argument from personal incredulity.  I can't believe people understood about this.  I haven't looked into it.  I haven't researched it.  I haven't figured out what people did or didn't know.  But I just can't believe that they knew about embryos.  Therefore, God must have said it.  And I will use that as evidence that there's a God and the Koran points us to it.  That is fallacy upon fallacy right there.

Now, that doesn't mean that your conclusion is necessarily wrong, but it does mean that you can't get to that conclusion with what you've provided and how you've provided it.  I'll give you an example that I came across yesterday.  Yesterday I was at the mall and I was talking to an employee at a clothing store who said that she was positive that There was some external force that had brain control technology and that they were controlling her mind, making her think things that she didn't want to and wouldn't normally think and were controlling her dreams.  And so I asked her, how do you know that?  And she said, well, it couldn't be any other way.  And so I said, well, what are the odds that you've uncovered this conspiracy and that there are all of these unknown forces that are conspiring together to make you think weird things and change your dreams?  Or a far more likely explanation is... You need help.
Well, let's set aside that.  Let's set aside this notion of whether or not it's far more likely.  My statement to you was not, you are wrong about God, and here's how they actually knew.
Well, here's, I mean, I want to put a pin in the end of this.  And that is that her response was, you need to prove to me that nobody is controlling my mind.

That's exactly the same thing that you just did.  But here's the thing.  You've proposed God as an explanation for how the Quran describes an embryo.  And I would argue that a God would know and have a better understanding of an embryo than chewed gum.  But you're proposing that explanation because you think it's the only one.  I proposed an alternate explanation.  And now, in order for yours to be the only one, you actually have to show why my other one can't be correct.  I'm not saying which one is right.  I'm just saying there are other potential explanations.  How did you rule them out?
Yeah, that's a good question.

Well, it's one that I would love for you to chew on and then maybe call back in next week.  It definitely shows that you've come up with this.  We've talked about plausible explanations and what we would hope to see.  Unless you have that on hand, I think that it would probably be a good idea to wait and see if you've got something better next week.
I had to say a couple of other things regarding the scientific... Now, there's one that I came across about the origin of the universe, and I'll get to that in a second.
About the what?
The origin?  The origin of the universe.
Oh, okay.  I just couldn't understand you.  Sorry, go ahead.

So I'm going to talk about that in just a few seconds, in just a minute or two.  But before that, I came across something very interesting.  That's why I was thinking about it, because I don't know how much you know about the jihad, or Muslims have to... Go to Mecca for...

I think a lot of our... I know a little bit, and I'm sure Matt knows more, but I would love for you to... I mean, if you can sum it up very quickly, this is an educational show, so people who are watching...
Sure.
Go ahead.

This is what I've come to on my own basis.  This isn't any scholarly thing, or maybe, I'm not sure.  But the universe stuff is more interesting, but I'll get to that in a second.  So what I came across is, for example, you see how the... Now... Correct me if I'm wrong.  Is it the earth that orbits around the sun or is it the other way around?
No, the earth orbits around the sun.

Okay, good.  Thanks for helping me out there.  So when you're in the Mecca, there's the big holy mosque or the masjid.  When you go inside, there's the big cube, the square, black square cube that people usually take seven... Walk around it seven times.  Basically, circular motion.
Hold on.  Saad, do you... Is this convincing?  Is this something that you think that...
This is what you asked him to describe, though.
Okay.  Sorry.  Sorry.  Go ahead.  Yeah, they walk around.
I'm just trying to draw a parallel from the Earth orbiting around the Sun...
Yeah, that was his evidence.
Pilgrims walking around the square.
Kids play ring around the rosy.

Well, the sun's not black, it's not square, and we don't just go around it seven times.  So apart from somebody goes around something and the earth goes around something, I don't know how those two are connected.
Yeah, and really, I mean, let's take a moment of honesty for a second.  Is that convincing?  Is that really convincing, Saad?
To Muslims like me, yes.

Well, to people who've already made up their mind, I totally get it.  But I would hope that you would have the same standards that we would have, that you would want to know the same things for good reasons as we do.  Because you're not going to hold yourself to a much lower standard than you would expect other people to, because I would hope that you would care about yourself more than that.  Why is this... so much more convincing to a Muslim than a non-Muslim.  You're saying people walk around a cube.

Let's imagine that it's actually a clear representation of the sun, and when you walk in, you always walk in it, you keep going around the same.  We already knew that the earth orbits the sun long before Islam even became a thing.  So how would people doing something... that is exactly what the Earth does, attest to the truth of the religion, and now you've got to go to what they're doing is even less directly analogous than my description.  I don't understand how this could possibly be convincing.  Here's something we already know, and humans mimic it, and so that shows that the Quran is true?  That's just bizarre.
I mean, not even that humans mimic it.  It's just a strange observation.

Well, just my observation.  So I'm not exactly sure.  Like I said, I'm not exactly sure how long ago people knew about it.  Earth rolls around the sun.  I'm not sure if Aristotle or Socrates or any of these guys knew about it.  So if I'm wrong about it, you can correct me.
We did.  Yeah.
But considering Galileo was put in prison for it, but.

Yeah.  So, Saad, I hope that you call in next week.  I hope that in your next round of investigation, you don't just look for things that are going to confirm what you already think.  Open yourself up to just looking for evidence and where that evidence leads.

And when you Google Quran and science, also Google Quran and science debunked, and you'll find that most of the things that you're going to find have already been thoroughly addressed with the same type of objections that we're launching.  Because there's a reason.  I knew exactly where you were going with that verse about an embryo.
It's not because you came up with it.
Yeah, I didn't invent this today.
The vast majority of the arguments that we have have been had for hundreds of years.  So, anyway, take care.
I have the one about the mountains.  Sorry, the origin of the universe.  Can we just go on that before I hang up?

The thing is I have a bunch of other callers I want to get to.  Yeah, it's really not fair to them.  But next time, call earlier in the show.  You didn't get on our lines until much later, and that's why we weren't able to get to you and weren't able to give you time to explore this.
But I do appreciate the fact that you went with one thing and allowed us to address it rather than 20 things all at once, which happens.
It didn't devolve into name calling or anything like that.  It was respectful.  It took time.  And that's exemplary.  We don't agree, but I like it.  All right.  Take care, man.
So can I just say one last thing before I go?
Go for it, brother.

I'm going to leave you with these two statements, these two small lines from the Quran, and then we'll hang up.  Just for something for food for thought.  So this is first chapter 41, verse 11.  Then he turned to the heaven when it was smoked.  And the last line I'm going to tell you is chapter 21, verse 30.  Have not those who disbelieve known that the heavens and the earth were one connected entity?  And then we separated them.  I'll leave you at that.
Okay.  All right.  Take care, man.
